==German== ===Etymology=== Spread via the [[w:Lower Rhine|Lower Rhineland]] from {{der|de|gml|dingesdach}} and {{der|de|dum|dinsendach}} (both with variants). Probably from {{m|gem-pro||*þingsus-dagaz}} (“Day of Thingsus”). {{m|la|Thingsus}} is the attested {{etyl|la|-}} name of a Germanic god who may or may not be the same as {{l|ang|Tiw}} ({{cog|goh|Ziu}}, for whom compare {{m|de|Ziestag}}). Further particulars unsettled. Another theory is that it is the “Day of the [[Thing]]”. ''Dienstag'' is cognate with {{cog|nl|dinsdag}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ˈdiːnsˌtaːk/}} {{a|standard}} * {{audio|de|Dienstag.ogg|Audio}} * {{audio|de|De-Dienstag.ogg|Audio}} :* {{IPA|de|/ˈdiːnsˌtax/}} {{a|northern Germany and parts of central Germany; chiefly colloquial}} :* {{IPA|de|/ˈdiːnsˌtaːx/}} {{a|parts of central Germany; chiefly colloquial}} * {{homophones|de|Diensttag}} {{a|except possibly in very careful speech}} ===Noun=== {{de-noun|m|Dienstags|gen2=Dienstages|Dienstage}} # [[Tuesday]] ====Declension==== {{de-decl-noun-m|(e)s|e}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|de|Dienstagabend}} * {{l|de|dienstäglich}} * {{l|de|dienstags}} ===See also=== * {{l|de|Ergetag}} * {{l|de|Ziestag}} * {{list:days of the week/de}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}} [[Category:de:Days of the week]]
